props.synopsis: Canberra is grappling with the stubbornly high cost of housing, and many of the factors are out of the government's control — but it can control the types of properties added to the city's supply to cater for our growing population.

title.children: More people are living in the bush capital, but how well can they afford it?

image.altText: A bald man in a blue police uniform stands in front of a police car.

props.synopsis: ACT Policing says the majority of e-scooter riders are doing the right thing but they do have concerns about some behaviour, particularly given how vulnerable they are compared with other road users.

title.children: 'You’re not invulnerable': Canberra police warn e-scooter riders against taking risks, as Melbourne imposes ban

image.altText: Green grass on a rolling hill at the national arboretum

props.synopsis: Tree pollen season is already triggering hay fever in the national capital, and the start of grass pollen season could be just weeks away, according to experts.

title.children: Arboretum photos indicate Canberra could have 'earlier and above average grass pollen season'

image.altText: A man stands in front of a flower bed in full bloom.

props.synopsis: Flowers planted for Canberra's Floriade festival are blooming weeks ahead of schedule due to warmer weather, while commercial horticulturalists are having to adapt their planting to meet the changing seasons.

title.children: Floriade is looking bloomin' marvellous but the festival's flowers are opening weeks ahead of schedule

image.altText: A still shot from a police bodycam showing a man sitting in a car with his hands up being tasered.

props.synopsis: ACT Supreme Court Justice Louise Taylor says Nathaniel Coulter, 22, was tasered despite the fact he was sitting in a car wearing a seat belt and in a submissive position after a dramatic car chase.

title.children: 'Used to punish': Judge criticises tasering by police in Canberra man's arrest

image.altText: A close up of a man with blonde hair smiling with his dog on a porch.

props.synopsis: The right to disconnect means you can reasonably refuse to be contacted outside of work hours. For people tied to the 'digital leash' of phones and email this marks a substantial boost in their right to break free.

title.children: Are you checking work emails and answering calls after hours? It could end today

image.altText: A composite image of Linda Reynolds and Brittany Higgins.

props.synopsis: The witnesses have wrapped up their evidence and the legal teams are preparing their final pitches to the judge as the mammoth defamation trial between WA Senator Linda Reynolds and her ex-staffer Brittany Higgins nears its end. Here's what we've learned.

title.children: Here's what we know after three weeks of the Linda Reynolds vs Brittany Higgins defamation trial

image.altText: Qld heat Southbank sunbathers August 25

props.synopsis: It may be the last week of winter but temperatures are rising across Australia — and in several places, winter heat records have already been broken.

title.children: 'No reprieve in sight' to unseasonably hot weather after new winter records set

image.altText: A group of men in red berets stand in a huddle

props.synopsis: Hezbollah and Israel's war is escalating. Four Corners travelled to Lebanon's Hezbollah heartland and found a group determined to hit back.

title.children: Inside Hezbollah's heartland, a new front line in the Middle East's escalating conflict

image.altText: A man in a blue suit and red tie and a woman in a camel-coloured suit and white shirt

props.synopsis: Americans remain deeply polarised over their choice between Kamala Harris or Donald Trump in November's presidential election. In Australia, a new survey suggests one candidate has overwhelming support.

title.children: Harris or Trump? If Australians were voting, the result would be a landslide

props.synopsis: A senator is calling for the government to end its long-standing relationship with South Korea's Eastern Social Welfare Society after a Background Briefing investigation revealed the agency falsified documents in historical adoption cases, dating back to the 1980s.

title.children: Calls grow to end Australia's adoption ties with South Korea after scandal

image.altText: Woman holding a young toddler.

props.synopsis: Months after Australian aid worker Zomi Frankcom was killed in an Israeli air strike on her convoy her brother Mal sits down with 7.30 to relive that fateful day and talk about the missing pieces of the puzzle the Israeli government still have not shared.

title.children: Mal Frankcom wants IDF soldiers responsible for his sister Zomi's death 'convicted and punished'

image.altText: A man wearing a turban and pale red shirt holds a woman with a black shirt and black hair with her back to the camera

props.synopsis: Pawanjeet Heir was treated like a slave as she pursued the requirements for permanent residency in Australia. Her husband says she has been punished for speaking up.

title.children: Pawanjeet Heir's boss was running a migration scam. Speaking up put her visa at risk

image.altText: A digital board with multiple rows reading "cancelled".

props.synopsis: A long-awaited blueprint for the aviation sector will be handed down today, including a promise to establish a charter of rights for customers to seek cash refunds when their flights are cancelled or unreasonably delayed.

title.children: Airline 'Charter of Rights' to establish refunds for delayed or cancelled flights

image.altText: Yellow billboard next to busy street

props.synopsis: The Jacqui Lambie Network's implosion in Tasmania follows a growing list of Australian namesake parties that have quickly encountered turbulence.

title.children: Does the Lambie implosion show that 'personality politics' is doomed to fail?

image.altText: A man with grey hair and beard leans over bushfire bunker built into ground

props.synopsis: Daniel Katz installed a six-person bushfire bunker at his Bridgewater property after the 2019 Cudlee Creek bushfire, without first seeking planning approvals — now, the council have issued a removal notice — a decision which he is appealing.

title.children: Daniel Katz installed a 'last resort' bunker after fleeing a bushfire, but he's been told to remove it

image.altText: Woman with black dress and long wavy hair leans forward

props.synopsis: Michelle Brasier was told she had a 97 per cent chance of getting cancer. She chose to laugh about it.

title.children: Why comedian Michelle Brasier laughs about her dad's funeral and her brother's ashes

image.altText: Ukrainian emergency personnel work among the rubble of a destroyed hotel

props.synopsis: Reuters said it was urgently seeking more information, working with the authorities in Kramatorsk.

title.children: Reuters staff member missing after Russian strike on Ukrainian hotel

image.altText: Willie Rioli celebrates a goal against Fremantle

props.synopsis: Port Adelaide has done Carlton a huge favour with a crucial win in Perth over Fremantle, with the win killing the Dockers' finals hopes on the final day of the AFL's home and away season.

title.children: Carlton through to the finals, Fremantle out as Port Adelaide locks up top-two spot

image.altText: Jared Waerea-Hargreaves fends off Kieran Foran's tackle attempt

props.synopsis: The Sydney Roosters face a nervous wait after Jared Waerea-Hargreaves faces a potential suspension over a dangerous high hit in his side's win over the Gold Coast Titans.

title.children: 'Disappointing': Roosters coach hits out over Waerea-Hargreaves binning as potential suspension looms

image.altText: A woman with short blonde hair wearing a gold tracksuit top hands a tall baton to a young girl.

props.synopsis: Commonwealth Games Australia (CGA) oversees the allocation of millions of dollars of funding to different sports and has roles pushing for green and gold success at international events — but behind the scenes its boardroom has become divided.

title.children: The governance dispute that's split the top ranks of Australia's peak Commonwealth Games body

image.altText: An aerial view of emergency vehicles on a street

props.synopsis: Police use a taser to arrest a man at the scene of a crash and suspected stabbings at a busy intersection in Sydney's southern outskirts.

title.children: Police say man was driving when he stabbed woman in passenger seat and crashed car in Sydney

image.altText: Bill Shorten at a press conference

props.synopsis: NDIS Minister Bill Shorten defends reforms to the disability scheme passed last week, saying the $14 billion in savings come from "cost reductions", not cuts.

title.children: 'This is not a cut': Shorten defends NDIS reforms that will save government $14b

image.altText: Golf-ball sized hail.

props.synopsis: Golfball-sized hail has pelted parts of Victoria, with a severe thunderstorm warning now issued for Melbourne.

title.children: Wild weather hits Victoria, with 'golfball-sized' hail and gusts of 150kph

image.altText: Lia and Eva election night composite 2

props.synopsis: Eye-watering debt, entrenched Indigenous disadvantage and a public at its wit's end with high rates of crime spell a tough four years ahead for incoming chief minister Lia Finocchiaro and her new-look team.

title.children: A political earthquake has shattered the NT's Labor party, leaving the CLP with a monumental task ahead

image.altText: Jonathan Simonds wears anti-war badges including one that says 'not another bomb'.

props.synopsis: While America's Democratic diehards enjoyed pep talks and pop music at their party-vibes convention this week, a smaller panel event on the sidelines was striking a very different tone.

title.children: Why some Democrats think a 'boneheaded mistake' could threaten Kamala Harris's election chances

image.altText: Half a dozen special police forces stand in full helmet and camo gear

props.synopsis: Officers arrested a suspect during a raid on a hostel for asylum seekers on Saturday, not far from the scene of the attack.

title.children: German police say suspect confessed to fatal knife attack at festival

image.altText: Takuya Shiota wears full PPE including a breathing mask with a white hood tightened around the outside of his face as he cleans.

props.synopsis: Dying a lonely death is an increasing problem in Japan, and it's not just due to its aging population, with a lack of community among the factors isolating people.

title.children: As Japan ages, a terrifying proposition is emerging: Dying alone and no-one finding your body for years

image.altText: Black writing on a white piece of paper with blue reflections

props.synopsis: Despite cuts to regulated power prices, some consumers are paying more than double the benchmark. Advocates say the system is broken.

title.children: Advocates decry 'failing' protections for energy consumers as some pay 'double' benchmark price

image.altText: An overhead shot of a town with houses and red dirt.

props.synopsis: Once thriving gold rush towns in Western Australia's Murchison region now lie deserted. There's fears other towns could be headed the same way.

title.children: With millions of dollars trucked out and very little coming back in, what do these remote mining towns do to survive?

image.altText: Two rugby leage commentators look surprised and each hold a hand up by their side.

props.synopsis: Locals in the NSW Upper Hunter are reeling from two earthquakes that hit the regional town in as many days. Authorities are still assessing the extent of the damage.

title.children: 'Never felt anything like that': How Upper Hunter earthquakes cracked windows, interrupted footy commentary

image.altText: Two women standing on a rocky beach beside palm trees

props.synopsis: This last undeveloped headland on Cairns' northern beaches is now at the centre of a fierce fight between the Queensland government and opposition as the state election looms.

title.children: The $8m 'slice of paradise' at the heart of a battle for one of Queensland's marginal state seats

image.altText: Mountainous rocks peek through surrounding gum tree forests.

props.synopsis: There are hundreds of dormant and extinct volcanoes across south-east Australia. They aren't likely to burst into life but it is "almost a given" that a new volcano will form somewhere else, according to a geosciences lecturer.

title.children: New volcanoes will erupt in Australia's south-east but whether that could happen in 100 years — or 5,000 — isn't known

image.altText: A middle aged white woman with long blonde hair sitting on a park bench

props.synopsis: Annual drug overdose deaths in Australia have almost doubled over the past 20 years. Advocates say it's time governments change the way they tackle the issue.

title.children: When police came to her door, Jen was worried her daughter had been arrested. The reality was far worse

image.altText: Chris Pearson portrait

props.synopsis: An inquiry ordered following a Four Corners investigation into the Public Trustee concluded that the agency's actions "in the main … were appropriate". Refunds and a misplaced account tell a different story.

title.children: Facing questions from the ABC, the Public Trustee found a client's misplaced account containing $73,000
